Award.AwardTitle: Integrative 3-D Modeling of Upper Mantle Flow and Melting Beneath the Lau Basin
Award.AbstractNarration: Lau Basin is a site of backarc seafloor spreading behind the adjacent Tonga Trench and Arc system, and is a particularly good field laboratory for studies of backarc spreading where models are well constrained by seismic and geochemical data. This study will use a combination of geodynamical and geochemical modeling methods to characterize 3-D flow in the mantle beneath the spreading centers (which are analogous to mid-ocean spreading centers such as the Mid-Atlantic Ridge) in the Lau Basin. The aim of this research is to understand how various factors such as spreading rate and proximity to the adjacent subducting slab and volcanic arc affect mantle processes beneath the spreading system. Broader impacts include the development of new analytical tools, educational outreach programs for minority students at local schools, involving undergraduate students in the research program and support for an early career female scientist.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the flow of the Earth’s mantle around slabs, which are cold bodies in the mantle that represent old tectonic plates recycled in the Earth’s interior. The main tool used here was the numerical modeling of mantle flow based on physical principles.

 

In a series of models, the slab was a rigid sheet sinking through the mantle while global mantle flow produced currents against the slab. We determined conditions for which these current run parallel and perpendicular to the trench and compared these predictions with observations of seismic anisotropy in many actual subduction zones. In particular we found that flow beneath the slab in the Tonga-Kermadec subduction zone is parallel to the trench because the slab impinges on the lower mantle. The slab forms an obstruction to global mantle flow, which proceeds along the slab until it finds an escape route at the end of the subduction zone. By contrast, in Alaska, flow is perpendicular to the trench because the slab stops in the upper mantle and flow is able to pass beneath the slab edge and does not need to be redirected. The view of slab as an obstruction to large-scale mantle flow leads to significant revision to the general view of mantle flow but is well justified based on the relative cold and therefore strength of the slab compared to surrounding mantle. Similar concepts explain the vast majority of the 25 subduction zones for which the direction of mantle flow underneath the slab is constrained by seismic methods.

 

In another series of models, we let the slab deform and its subduction rate adjust to pressure gradients related to the thermal structure of the plate underneath which it sinks, leading to systematic variations in subduction rate. Subduction is slower underneath the colder portions of the overriding plate where the mantle more viscous, which 2) increases drag and 2) decreases slab dip through increased suction between the slab and the overriding plate. The predictions compare favorably against observations in the Andes.

 

Project results were communicated at several scientific meetings and through four publications (doi 10.1016/j.epsl.2013.04.018, 10.1002/2014GL060914, 10.1002/2014GC005441, and 10.1016/j.jog.2016.02.006)

 

Three postdoctoral scientists were involved in the work reported here. Two of them are female and the third a native of Spain, bringing diversity to the field.

 

Software used to calculate melt propagation in these models, albeit not used in the publications mentioned above, was tested, documented, and made publically available (currently through the PI’s website but soon through GitHub). A training session at the University of Houston was conducted in early 2016.
